qas.question: What is the use of a transistor?

answers.text: to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power

qas.question: What is a transistor made of?
What is the minimum amount of external connection terminals to call an item a transistor?
Why does a transistor increase a signal?

answers.text: the controlled (output) power can be higher than the controlling (input) power

plausible_answers.text: to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power

qas.question: What is an integrated circuit used for?
Where are most semiconductor devices found?
What are integrated circuits made of?
How many transistors are embedded in most integrated circuits?
What controls how strong a signal is?

context: A transistor is a semiconductor device used <a0_0><b5_0>to amplify or switch electronic signals and electrical power<b5_0/><a0_0/>. It is composed of <a1_0><b7_0>semiconductor material<b7_0/><a1_0/> with at least <a2_0><b8_0>three<b8_0/><a2_0/> terminals for connection to an external circuit. A voltage or current applied to one pair of the transistor's terminals changes the current through another pair of terminals. Because <a3_0><b9_0>the controlled (output) power<b9_0/> can be higher than the controlling (input) power<a3_0/>, a transistor can amplify a signal. Today, some transistors are packaged individually, but many more are found <a4_0><b6_0>embedded in integrated circuits<b6_0/><a4_0/>.
